data.title: 119 schools included in Onondaga County's orange and yellow zones: See list here
data.meta_description: Nearly 120 schools are now in Onondaga County's orange or yellow zones and must meet coronavirus testing requirements to remain open.  A map released by the county lays out exactly which schools fall into the zones, where coronavirus infection rates are increasing. Onondaga County Orange and Yellow Zone Schools by Jana Barnello on Scribd. Parts of the city of Syracuse, Solvay, DeWitt and Lyncourt were added to the orange zone on Monday.
data.text:
Nearly 120 schools are now in or zones and must meet coronavirus testing requirements to remain open.

A map released by the county lays out exactly which schools fall into the zones, where coronavirus infection rates are increasing.

Parts of the city of Syracuse, Solvay, DeWitt and Lyncourt were .In orange zones, , clean, and then to reopen the school, all students and staff returning to the building must test negative for COVID-19. After that, schools must test 25 percent of students and staff per week.

However, Solvay schools will not have to meet orange zone testing because the part of Solvay added to the orange zone does not include the areas where Solvay Elementary and Solvay High School sit, according to the map.

MORE:

County leaders are asking the state to relax the testing rules in the orange zone, but have so far not been granted any exceptions.

Additionally, on Monday, which brings more schools under a rule to test 20 percent of its students and staff to remain open for in-person learning.

In both the orange and yellow zones, schools can "test out" of the weekly requirement by showing that their schools have lower infection rates than the rest of the zone in which they lie after two weeks of testing.

Onondaga County Executive Ryan McMahon said several yellow zone schools had already met this requirement and "graduated out" of more weekly testing. Those schools are Liverpool, parts of North Syracuse schools (although more were added in with the expansion of the yellow zone), Baldwinsville and East Syracuse-Minoa.

School districts that must now test students in the newly expanded yellow zone are Fayetteville-Manlius, North Syracuse, Jamesville-DeWitt, West Genesee, Westhill and a number of Catholic and private schools.
